latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

item.latestTitle: A joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to equal rights for men and women.

policyArea.name: Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: By Mrs. CAROLYN B. MALONEY of New York:H.J. Res. 56.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:``Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following: Article V--Amendment. The Congress,whenever two thirds of both Houses shall deem it necessary,shall propose Amendments to this Constitution, or, on theApplication of the Legislatures of two thirds of the severalStates, shall call a Convention for proposing Amendments,which, in either Case, shall be valid to all Intents andPurposes, as Part of this Constitution, when ratified by theLegislatures of three fourths of the several States or byConventions in three fourths thereof, as the one or the otherMode of Ratification may be proposed by the Congress;Provided that no Amendment which may be made prior to theYear One thousand eight hundred and eight shall in any Manneraffect the first and fourth Clauses in the Ninth Section ofthe first Article; and that no State, without its Consent,shall be deprived of its equal Suffrage in the Senate.''[Page H5347]

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution and Civil Justice.

item.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to equal rights for men and women.
Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to equal rights for men and women.

bill.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relative to equal rights for men and women.

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text:
Constitutional Amendment - Declares that women shall have equal rights in the United States and every place subject to its jurisdiction.

Prohibits the United States or any state from denying or abridging equal rights under the law on account of sex.
Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution and Civil Justice.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR E1202-1203)

policyArea.name: Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
